it is relatively simple to see that Bmn = 0 when m is even and n is odd, since in
that case An() = 0  Am(). Hence mn = Bmn = 0 and Bombieris conjecture
is correct when m is even and n is odd. Also, Bshouty and Hengartner [5] showed
that the conjecture is true for analytic variations of the Koebe function and for
functions with real coecients (a simpler proof of the latter appeared in [12]).
Some related results are given in the recent article [1].

Recently, Leung [10] developed a variational method which allowed him to
show that m2  Bm2 for all m  3 and that m3  Bm3 for all odd m  5. He
used the linear version of Loewners dierential equation
whose solutions are chains of univalent functions f (z, t) = et(z + a2(t)z2 + . . .),
t  0. Any one-slit function in S can be seen as the initial value f (z) = f (z, 0) of
such a solution (see [11]). The drive function  has the form (t) = ei(t), with
being real-valued and piecewise continuous on [0,). In the special case when

We have already observed that one can deduce the following corollary.
Corollary. Let m  n  2 be integers such that either (a), (b) or (c) in
Theorem 1 holds. Then Bombieris conjecture for this pair of integers is false.

We rst mention a criterion for the univalence of polynomials found by Dieudonne
Lemma 2 (Dieudonnes criterion). The polynomial p(z) = z + a2z2 + . . . + anzn
is univalent in D if and only if its associated polynomials
have no zeros in D for any choice of the parameter t  [0, ].
